item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Geospatial Analysis on Civilians Arrested by the Gun Trace Task Force
item.description:
Geospatial Analysis

This was a project I worked on that heavily relied on demographic data and geospatial analysis to meet the client’s needs. The dataset was curated while I was working at a previous company, one of the few datasets that curate arrest and charges case data in Baltimore City that was related to the Gun Trace Task Force - whose current trials are still ongoing for the officers that have been charged. Unsure for legal reasons if I can be able to post the code made to web scrape the Maryland State Case Search: once I get an update, I’ll add it to a post or a separate project.

The goal and purpose of this map was to see where the civilians who were arrested lived, their race, age and what they were arrested for.

This analysis was taking all the addresses scraped on the case search engine, pretty scary right! Before I get ahead of myself, I had to properly set up my REnviron. and make sure that I had all libraries needed to run the script:

library(sp)
library(sf)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggmap)
library(maps)
library(tmap)
library(tmaptools)
library(htmlwidgets)

Most of these packages make it easier for me to manipulate the data visually or it allows me to transform shapefiles so that my data falls upon the correct geographical markers ~~ like streets, highways and in this case county lines within Baltimore City and the surrounding areas.

So here I found a free to use shapefile of Baltimore City and Baltimore County because, man these poo poo police officers were definitely making quota! FYI, when we did the initial webscrape these guys were arresting people all over MD! Sickening!

# setting up data ---------------------------------------------------------

# # load the data
county_sections <- readOGR("data/raw_data/md_counties/geo_export_mdc.shp")

# view attributes ---------- COUNTIES
class(county_sections)
extent(county_sections)
crs(county_sections)

plot(county_sections)

# lets filter down to only baltimore area zipcodes!
# we can filter for other zips after

# baltimore only
baltimore_county <- subset(county_sections, geodesc == "Baltimore County")
baltimore_city <- subset(county_sections, geodesc == "Baltimore City")
city_county <- subset(county_sections, 
                      geodesc == "Baltimore County" | geodesc == "Baltimore City")

I had an address data set, but unfortunately the FULL address was in one column! Had to go ahead and just break that down. As you can see below, I extract the an address vector and call it bmoreadddy_unique because I only needed to see the unique set of addresses.

I then created an empty vector called geo_bmore which will hold the broken down columns and rows of the addresses that were collected.

# geocode normal addresses ------------------------------------------------
# just remember to reference unique list to find the rows that are messed up!
# then look by case number from bmore_address, then join to full data set bmore_demo (which will eventually replace
# mdcs_cop_demo_df() reference 'raw_code/demo_filters.R' file
bmoreaddy_unique = unique(bmore_address$full_address)

geo_bmore <- c()
# i <- 1
# hit limit will run again at lunch
# i = 6328 ~ end result
while(i <= length(bmoreaddy_unique)) {
  geo_bmore_row <- geocode_OSM(bmoreaddy_unique[i])
  if(is.null(geo_bmore_row)){
    i <- i + 1
    next;
  }
  geo_bmore_row <- tibble(obs_num = i, 
                          full_address = geo_bmore_row[[1]],
                          # up and down
                          lon = geo_bmore_row[[2]][1],
                          # left to right
                          lat = geo_bmore_row[[2]][2]
  )
  # creating geo_bmore sp object
  geo_bmore <- bind_rows(geo_bmore, geo_bmore_row)
  i <- i + 1
}

# Take a peek at problem address (ones that break the geocode code)
bmoreaddy_unique[i]
# Write down the bad ones!
i <- i+1

save(geo_bmore, 
     file = here::here("data/tidy_data",
                       "geo_bmore_unique_addy.rda"))

So…..if you’re not used to if, while or for loops…what just happened might’ve confused the heck out of you just now. It’s ok, I’m going to explain it as best as I can..

Basically what I’m telling R to do, is go through the vector and label each row a number, then geocode each row from the original data set. If the address does not end up being geodcoded, skip the row and go to the next row. BUT if the address was successfully geocoded, then add 4 new columns geo_bmore_row to the empty vector we created in the beginning of the code chunk geo_bmore. Thus created a new dataset of full addresses, connected with lat and lon and the observation number. The observation number allows us to trace it back to other datasets in case we need to easily join them later on in analysis.

We then bind, basically pasting together, the datasets together by rows thus created a clean data set of addresses and the connecting latitudes and longitudes. This process normally takes about 10-20 minutes, so don’t fret. I used the OSM search engine instead of Google’s because there were to many complications on the system I was running at the time of employment. OSM gave less stress ~

Next Chunk!

Remember earlier when I explained, or tried my best, that while loop and that it may skip some rows? Here is where I address the missing addresses. I needed to antijoin the final geocoded addreses, geo_bmore, with the original addresses scraped from the Maryland Case Search, bmore_address. Below are 3 examples of antijoining the two datasets using dplyr and two forms of baseR.

# quality control for missed addresses ------------------------------------
# not creating new variables, so im just going to do it like this
# three different ways to anti_join
# 1
no_geo_unique <- unique(bmore_address$full_address[!bmore_address$full_address%in%geo_bmore$full_address])

# 2
no_geo_case <- bmore_address[is.na(match(bmore_address$full_address, geo_bmore$full_address)), ]

# 3
anti_join(bmore_address, geo_bmore, by = "full_address")

Now that we have a dataset of all of the missing addresses that did not get geocoded, we are going to filter through the dataset and allow R to separate and clean the problematic rows that we could not address before!

# quality control workup --------------------------------------------------
no_geo = no_geo_case
# taking away so I can get unique values
no_geo = no_geo %>%
  select(-case_num)
# takes rowname col into actual rownames
no_geo = column_to_rownames(no_geo)
# only gives unique addresses and keeps rownames
no_geo = unique(no_geo)
# add rowname col back after only getting unique addys
# rownames basically = obs_num
# use this to join again
# no_geo = rownames_to_column(no_geo)


# separating the address string
problem_rows = as_tibble(str_split_fixed(no_geo$full_address,
                                         # telling R to separate by commas
                                         ", ",
                                         # there should be at least 5 separations
                                         n = 5))

# we only needed these columns which were rowname, full_address
problem_rows = paste0(str_c(problem_rows$V1,
                            ", ",
                            problem_rows$V3,
                            ", ",
                            problem_rows$V5
))


# converts from vector to df or tibble
problem_rows = enframe(problem_rows)

# renaming for future cleaning
colnames(problem_rows)[1] <- "rowname"
colnames(problem_rows)[2] <- "full_address"

# adds correct obs_num to tbl_df/tbl/data.frame
problem_rows = problem_rows %>%
  mutate(rowname = rownames(no_geo))

# sets appropriate "i" for while loop below. 
problem_rows = column_to_rownames(problem_rows)

# creating var
new_geo <- c()

i = 1
while(i <= length(problem_rows$full_address)) {
  no_geo_row <- geocode_OSM(problem_rows$full_address[i])
  if(is.null(no_geo_row)){
    i <- i + 1
    next;
  }
  new_geo_row <- tibble(obs_num = i, 
                        full_address = no_geo_row[[1]],
                        # up and down
                        lon = no_geo_row[[2]][1],
                        # left to right
                        lat = no_geo_row[[2]][2]
  )
  # creating geo_bmore sp object
  new_geo <- bind_rows(new_geo, new_geo_row)
  i <- i + 1
}

problem_rows$full_address[i]
i <- i+1

save(new_geo,
     file = here::here("data/tidy_data",
                       "new_geo.rda"))

The original while loop was used for the list of problematic addresses and then saved to the local disk for safe keeping. I know, I know! Why did you not just turn the loop into a function? Well I didn’t know that at this point and time in my career! But I definitely do it more later on in work!

Here is some cleaning, tidying and data maintenance I had to do before using them to map anything:

HINTS: - bmore_demo was a curated tidied dataset from all the case data that held age, race, name, address, court type, case type and other demographic data that was scraped and accumulated legally for THE FREE online using the Maryland Case Search Engine.

# collecting all data together --------------------------------------------
# these both have correct coords and addresses
# lets unite them together 
head(new_geo)
head(geo_bmore)

# lets rename new_geo coded addresses so there isn't a mix up
colnames(new_geo)[2] <- "geocoded_addresses"


# but first we need to make sure that addresses in new_geo will match addresses
# bmore_demo YIKES YIKES YIKES!
# renaming col for binding purposes
colnames(problem_rows)[2] <- "geocoded_address"

# problem_rows = no_geo, basically
matching = cbind(problem_rows, no_geo)

# join new_geo and matching by geocoded_addresses
new_geo = left_join(new_geo, matching, by = "geocoded_address")

# take away incorrect current $obs_num and $geocoded_address
new_geo = new_geo %>%
  select(-obs_num)

new_geo = new_geo %>%
  select(-geocoded_address)

# lets rearrange col order for perfect alignment
new_geo = new_geo[, c(3,4,1,2)]

# change rowname to finally correct obs_num
colnames(new_geo)[1] <- "obs_num"

# let's rbind with geo_bmore and finally start mapping!!!!!!!!!!
geo_bmore = rbind(geo_bmore, new_geo)
geo_bmore = geo_bmore %>%
  arrange(as.double(obs_num))


# RUN TO MATCH geo_bmore DATASET - comment out after running
# bmore_demo$full_address = paste0(str_c(bmore_demo$full_address, ", USA"))

# DO NOT RUN UNTIL ALL GEOCODES HAVE BEEN ACCOUNTED FOR
# lets use tmap package to see if we can get some coords
bmore_demo = left_join(geo_bmore, bmore_demo, by = "full_address")
# nrow(bmore_demo)
# 6721

# FILTER FOR ONLY DISTRICT COURT CASES
bmore_demo <- bmore_demo %>%
  filter(case_type_2 != "Other")
# nrow(bmore_demo)
# 6078 ~ geocoded
# 7687 ~ filtered
# 7748 ~ original # cases

# Filter out Circuit Court cases
bmore_demo <- bmore_demo[str_detect(bmore_demo$court, "District"),]

So if you made it this far to see the maps….well good luck because I can only show you the code because of our American Justice System, and the fact that I respect my old employer lol…

This is where I allow my artist creativity run wild…within the confines of R and Leaflet!

# making the base map vars ------------------------------------------------

                         domain = unique(bmoredemo_markers1$sex_id))
# mult races

# age

                    domain = bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs)

Now I know you guys are like, why only two genders… well our legal justice system doesn’t see otherwise unfortunately so there’s a whole subset of data unaccounted for to go along with broken window policing… oh yea..if you’re guessing hate crimes or sex workers being arrested…you were on the right path. Unfortunately our client was really interested on the impact these officers had on the urban community so they were interested to see whether the officers were indeed practicing broken window policing OR was it a big misunderstanding?

I mean…our company alone scraped over 10,000 cases in a 7-10 year time frame…while the news under reported per usual. So…they were just being shit cops. The race categories were WHITE, BLACK, and OTHER.

Below is where all the work from above, and the work not seen that will be uploaded to other projects..cough cough. The map was interactive and super colorful. Like I mentioned earlier, let me see if I can post a picture here after talking to my previoud employer.

             weight = 3,
             radius = 40,
             stroke = TRUE,
             fillOpacity = 0.8,
             color = ~sex_icons(sex_id),
             label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$sex_id),
             options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>%
  addLegend("bottomleft",
            colors = c( "#53a097", "#0d2666", "#682140"),
            labels = c("Male", "Female", "Other/Unknown"),
            title = "Cases by Sex",
            group = "Female/Male",
            labFormat = labelFormat()) %>%
  addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1,
             lng = ~lon,
             lat = ~lat,
             group = "Age",
             weight = 2,
             radius = 25,
             stroke = TRUE,
             fillOpacity = 0.5,
             color = ~pal(age_yrs),
             label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs),
             options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>%
  addLegend("bottomleft",
            pal = pal,
            values = bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs,

            group = "Age") %>%
  addLayersControl(overlayGroups = c("City",
                                     "County"),
                   baseGroups = c("Points",

                                  "Female/Male",

                   options = layersControlOptions(collapsed = TRUE, autoZIndex = TRUE)) %>%

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask
